lang.name: default
lang.p: adding pages is quite simple if you know how to do it

lang.name: default
lang.h3: (Mini) PAGE HOWTO: What you need to do to add pages to your projects

ol.li: Add a file with the name [prefix]_[pagename].xml

Entries in [servletname].prop.in. For each page you some entries in the servlet config file:
A page can be part of a pageflow: (for dynamic content mostly)
<prop name="context.pageflow.Def.1">[pagename]</prop>
A page request configuration: possibly multiple if this page is associated with one or more IWrappers
<prop name="pagerequest.[pagename].classname"> de.schlund.pfixcore.workflow.app.StaticState</prop>

Entries in depend.xml.in:
associate the page with a servlet in the navigation:
<navigation>
<page name="[pagename]" handler="/xml/[servletname]"/>
<!-- more pages here -->
</navigation>
associate the page with a layout from the xml/ directory
<standardpage name="[pagename]" xml="[projectname]/xml/sample_layout.xml"/>

lang.name: default
lang.p: Here is an example page. What functions are already in the pfx-namespace? Well find out for yourself, unless someone else documents this.

Basically pages consist of 'parts' that can include each other, each page has to have a content part, this is the one that is included by the stylesheets. Other parts are only included via the pfx:include method.
Wether you make many small parts or a few large ones is entirely up to your personal philosophy.

p.tt:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
<include_parts xmlns:ixsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:pfx="http://www.schlund.de/pustefix/core">
<part name="content">
<product name="default">
<lang name="default">
[put your html code here]
<pfx:include part="anotherpart"/>
</lang>
</product>
</part>

lang.p: If your new text is not showing up likely you forgot to include the "part" in another part that is already displayed, for example the "content" part.
